issues.description: The problem statement (UML and tasks) specifies getTotalNumberOfStudents() should return an int, but the solution implements getTotalNumberOfStudents() returning a StudentCount object (a custom wrapper). This introduces a return-type mismatch across artifacts and adds an extra class (StudentCount) that is not mentioned in the problem statement or present in the template. Students reading the problem and template will expect an int return type (and likely implement it that way), while the solution uses a different type — this can cause confusion about the expected API and may break automated checks or student comparisons against the reference solution.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the method return type consistent with the problem specification. Preferred fix: change the solution to have getTotalNumberOfStudents() return an int (sum of inscribed and guest students) and remove the StudentCount wrapper class (update any solution usages accordingly, e.g. getNameAndTotalNumberOfStudents() should call getTotalNumberOfStudents() directly). Alternatively, if the StudentCount wrapper is intentional, update the problem statement (UML and task descriptions) and the template to declare/introduce StudentCount and to specify getTotalNumberOfStudents(): StudentCount so students are guided to the same API.

issues.description: The problem statement (and its UML) specifies getTotalNumberOfStudents() with a return type of int, i.e. the total number of students as a primitive integer. The solution implementation, however, introduces a new class StudentCount and implements getTotalNumberOfStudents() to return a StudentCount object. This introduces a new identifier (StudentCount) for the same conceptual entity (the total number of students) that is not present in the problem statement or template and changes the expected API. Students reading the exercise (which explicitly hints to check the UML return type) may be confused about whether they should use a primitive int or a StudentCount wrapper, creating unnecessary cognitive load and a mismatch between requirements and the reference solution.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the representation of the total student count across artifacts. Either (A) change the solution to have getTotalNumberOfStudents() return a primitive int (and remove or stop using the StudentCount wrapper), which matches the UML and exercise text, or (B) update the problem statement and UML to document and justify the StudentCount class as the intended return type (and add StudentCount to the template). Option A is preferable to avoid introducing an extra wrapper that is not mentioned in the exercise.
